I worked as a "professional" state correctional officer and as an 
EMT/deputy in a regional jail. I agree that the officer's actions were 
totally out of line, both in policy and criminal actions. I saw actions 
from other officers and medics that appeared courteous and within 
appropriate policy. We sometimes felt that video of our every move was a 
bit "big brother", but it is for this exact reason. It also serves as 
defense against false claims of inappropriate behaviors. For example, had 
she slipped or intentionally hit her head in an attempt to sue, the video 
would have showed the truth...﻿
police officer is charged with aggravated battery and official misconduct﻿

The officer who shoved the lady head-first into the concrete is Michael 
Hart, a 19 year veteran of the north suburban police department. He 
resigned after the incident, plead guilty to official misconduct, a felony, 
and received two years probation and lost his pension, which is a big, big 
loss for him and his 19 years of "service."

He did make a statement in court, apologized for actions and seemed 
genuinely remorseful about his actions. The victim, still has a lawsuit 
that and she will get some serious money which she deserves. The assault 
broke her eye socket and she lost a few teeth.﻿

Michael Hart, 45, apologized to the victim during his sentencing at the 
Leighton Criminal Court Building, saying he acted out of frustration. She, 
however, was not in court. The charges came after an attorney for the 
victim, Cassandra Feuerstein, filed a brutality lawsuit last year and 
released a police video of the incident that attracted widespread attention 
on the Internet. The video captured Hart shoving Feuerstein from behind 
after he became upset when she wouldn't look into the camera for a booking 
photo in March 2013, Cook County prosecutors said. She had been arrested 
for drunken driving and later pleaded guilty. Feuerstein, a receptionist 
and mother of two from Chicago, fell and hit her face on the bench, 
breaking her eye socket and loosening some teeth. Hart, a 19-year veteran 
of the north suburban police department, resigned last year after Skokie 
officials told him they would seek to fire him over the incident. He will 
lose his pension as a result of pleading guilty to the felony count, 
according to his attorney, Jed Stone. Hart was sentenced to two years of 
probation as part of the plea deal.﻿

+Michael Illes Actually if you pause the clip and look closer, the police 
officer is holding her left arm and pushed her down the hallway so that she 
puts her right hand on the door frame to stop herself from slamming into 
that. That's when he shoves her forward into the room (which he was already 
in the motion of doing before she ever put a hand on the door frame, so he 
wasn't forcing her forward because he thought she was resisting, he was 
already doing it because he was upset). You are right that she probably 
could've been able to catch herself a little if she hadn't been intoxicated 
and/or holding the door frame a little, but that doesn't change the fact 
that she was intoxicated and the officer knew that, and she did go face 
first into the bench and he just walked away. I realize it must be 
frustrating dealing with drunk people all the time, but he shouldn't have 
choose to be a cop if he couldn't deal with ALL types of people in a 
professional and respectful manner. I have police officers in my family so 
I've heard all the horror stories about how people act towards cops when 
they get arrested; but nothing like what happened here would ever be 
tolerated by a cop. After all, they are an officer of the law, there to 
SERVE & PROTECT. So they are supposed to be held to a higher standard than 
the everyday citizen. It might not be fair, but that's the way it is. Like 
I said before, don't take the job if you can't handle it, or if you feel 
yourself getting to the point of being that upset, ask someone else to step 
in for a minute so something like this doesn't happen. That's why they call 
it "Back Up." The other officers are there to help you when you need it.

Update from Chicago Tribune:
"...Feuerstein, a receptionist and mother of two from Chicago, fell and hit 
her face on the bench, breaking her eye socket and loosening some teeth.

Hart, a 19-year veteran of the north suburban police department, resigned 
last year after Skokie officials told him they would seek to fire him over 
the incident. He will lose his pension as a result of pleading guilty to 
the felony count, according to his attorney, Jed Stone. Hart was sentenced 
to two years of probation as part of the plea deal.

A written apology by Hart was read aloud before Judge Matthew Coghlan 
imposed the sentence.

"I did not intend to or want to harm you in any way," Hart said. "I acted 
in frustration and not out of anger or meanness.

"I'm sorry for the injuries I caused you," he said. "I hope you can accept 
my heartfelt apology."

Prosecutors told the judge that Feuerstein did not oppose the plea deal 
that spared Hart prison time.

Feuerstein's federal lawsuit names the village of Skokie as a defendant in 
addition to Hart. On Wednesday, her attorney made a filing that asked the 
judge to allow the civil case to move forward after attempts at a 
settlement failed.

The village had sought to delay the lawsuit until the criminal case was 
resolved.﻿

over Hart's sentence of probation. This has been horrific and devastating 
for my family as well as myself. I didn't oppose the State's Attorney and 
Judge Coghlan's sentence because Michael Hart will never be able to hold 
the honorable position of a police officer again. He will not collect a 
pension from the Village of Skokie and he's now a convicted felon.

Hart's conviction behind me, I can start moving towards that, the healing 
process, and on with my life. I truly hope that the Village of Skokie will

finally removed from their police force, by working with my attorneys to 
resolve the civil case swiftly and fairly.﻿

the early 60's and was supposed to help with safety. What has transpired 
since is the creation of the "bully" culture in the police community. Cops 
don't show the proper respect for the individual, or their civil rights.
They order people around, make illegal demands (lets see some I.D.) and 
generally treat the citizens that they take an oath to protect like 
prisoners of war. They are arrogant, demanding, fascist thugs. And until 
the police departments change the way they screen applicants and train 
officers to respect individual rights and the 1st, 4th, and 5th amendments, 
then nothing will change.

+Julz Rose we don't have the full story of why he lost his temper. When he 
pushed her he didnt' expect her to dive toward the 'bed', which is solid 
concrete. She clearly was too out of it to realize that the 'bed' would not 
break her fall. Instead of covering her face for the crash she tried to 
dive into the thing face first, probably thinking that her 'bed' for the 
night was a soft cushioned affair. That would be like diving into a wading 
pool with someone shoving you from behind for good measure. No one knows 
what she said to them while being processed. It's a stressful job, 
sometimes people lose control of themselves on a particularly bad day, or 
series of bad days. it is going to happen sometimes that circumstances 
combine and flawed human beings make big mistakes like this. She was 
probably closing her eyes to the whole thing from start to finish. Driven 
downtown with her eyes closed, fingerprinted with her eyes closed, wouldn't 
open her eyes for the mug shot, kept her eyes closed while the cop was 
returning to her to her cell.....he shoved her and didn't realize she 
wasn't even watching . By the time she opened her eyes she was already on a 
collision course with the concrete slab. Stupid bitch, but unfortunate that 
she was hurt. No one deserves a severe injury like that for keeping their 
eyes closed.
